statement.p: Explain why the vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \\ -3 \\ -4 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ 3 \\ 3 \\ -5 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -6 \\ -6 \\ -6 \\ 10 \\ -6 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -1 \\ 3 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ -5 \\ -9 \\ 6 \\ 12 \end{array}\right] are or are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5

answer.p: The vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \\ -3 \\ -4 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ 3 \\ 3 \\ -5 \\ 3 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -6 \\ -6 \\ -6 \\ 10 \\ -6 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -1 \\ 3 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ -5 \\ -9 \\ 6 \\ 12 \end{array}\right] are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5.
